III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12327 (5) (c) Special Evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the
evaluation, an agency shall complete a written
report that includes all of the following
information.
(c) Dates and places of contacts, names of
persons interviewed, and names of the
interviewers. If children are interviewed, their last
names may not be included in the report.
1 of 2 special investigation reports reviewed, one report reported the youth full name
in the report.
CPA Rule 400. 12418 (2) (b) Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service
plans for each child and parent or parents, as
follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial
removal and at least once every 90 calendar
days thereafter.
1 of 6 active foster care files reviewed, 1 report dated 11/16/22 – 2/13/23 was not
uploaded into the system.
REPEAT VIOLATION FROM RENEWAL DATED 9/16/21 & CAP

APPROVED 9/17/21 & INTERIM EVALUATION COMPLETED 11/18/22 &
CAP APPROVED 3/16/23.
CPA RULE 400.12509 (3) (O) Independent living record.
(3) The case record must contain all of the
following information and documentation,
which must be recorded within 30 calendar
days after placement in independent living and
updated at least once every 90 calendar days:
(o) Service plans as required in R400.12419
and Rule 400.12420. If the youth has biological
children, the service plan must address the
living arrangement for the child or children,
visitation/parenting time with the youth ‘s
biological children or a clear explanation why
this is not possible or appropriate.
1 of 3 independent living files reviewed, 1 report dated 1/20/23 – 4/19/23 was

(1) There must be a mutual agreement between

DHHS FOM Policy Treatment plans Agreement and Signature:
722.08D
Once completed and approved, the
caseworker
Must obtain signatures from the following
Individuals, as applicable:
• Caseworker
• Supervisor

• Second line supervisor, when sibling in
care are place apart.
• Parents who are a member of a
participating household.
• Youth ages 14 and older.
• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and
unrelated court – ordered caregivers.
Parents/legal guardians, youths, and caregivers
must check yes or no for the following when signing
the treatment plan:
• I agree with the Case Service Plan and Parent
Agency Treatment Plan.
• I have been provided a copy of the Case
Service Plan and Parent Agency Treatment
Plan to review, and I will have the opportunity
to express my disagreement with the Case
Service Plan and Parent Agency Treatment
Plan when the information is presented to
court.
Note: If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to
sign the treatment plan, the caseworker must
identify and document actions needed to secure the
parent’s and/or youth’s participation in service
planning and compliance with the treatment plan.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all
applicable individuals and upload the signatures
pages into the electronic case record within 30 days
of the report date.
7 of 9 open case files reviewed (4 foster care, 3 IL) were either missing required
signatures on Parent Agency Treatment Plans or contained signatures obtained
outside of the policy timeframe and or the boxes were not checked. The missing/late
signatures were cited for 17 of the 26 PATP’s reviewed.

The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows.
SI #2023C0000079, completed on 4/6/23 and the CAP was accepted on 4/10/23.
The agency was in violation with Rules 400.12206 (1) Staff qualifications, and
400.12503(2) (e) Policy and Procedures. The agency is following their CAP that
was submitted on 4/10/23.
Interim Inspection report on completed on 11/18/2022. CAP was approved on
3/16/23 due to installation of CWLM system. The agency was in violations with
rule 400.12326 (1)(f) Borrowed home, 400.12418 (2) (b) Development of service
plans, DHHS policy 722-6B Family Team Meeting, and DHHS policy 722-08D
Treatment plans agreement and signature. The agency has some repeat
violations for this renewal inspection.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The CAA was discussed with the Director of the program. The Chief Administrator
reported that barriers this past year include staffing issues. The agency casework
team has stabilized, and the team is focusing on finding systems that works well
for the team. The CA reported that disruptions in staffing cause a lot of struggles
with maintaining systems. She reported that systemic factors also include data
management to address MISEP, which is requiring a lot of attention beyond the
work that is needed to be completed. She reported human error is always a
factor. The CA reported the agency had to become flexible with systems based
on the different staffing team that included managers/supervisors and staff. She
reported staff turnover may affect how the agency is meeting their goals, but the
agency continues to show more and more improvement. She reported
improvement is found in meeting medicals, dentals, and sibling visits to name a
few for the youth in care.
Financial Overview
The agency provided their annual audit by an independent certified public
accountant an annual budget for the current fiscal year. No concerns were noted.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff interviewed reported that they love the fact that the agency is flexible with the
staff schedules. The staff enjoys working with families. Staff feels supported by
their manager and supervisor but stated, more staff is needed to perform the

duties that is required for the different programs. Staff reported the agency need
more supervisors to work with the team because the management team is
strength pretty thin at this point. Staff discussed the turnover and how it affects
their day-to-day routine of carrying out their job duties. The theme was the agency
needs to hire more staff.
No youth were interviewed by this Consultant.
Description of Agency Walk Through
There were no areas of safety concerns noted in the areas of the facility.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were 2 safety alerts.
Concern 1:
The foster parents have a spa. There is no rescue equipment
available and no alarm on the exterior door that leads to the spa.
Resolution:
The foster parents reported that the spa was not being used and
the water has been drained from the spa. The foster parents purchased and
installed a door alarm on the exterior door leading to the spa and purchased rescue
equipment. The home is now compliant with this safety issue. Verified and dated
by the agency on 8/9/23. Photos attached to the alert.
Concern 2:
The relative caregivers refused access to the basement of the home. The foster
children reported they are allowed to go into the basement, but it's mainly their
grandfather's area. The relative caregivers reported they do not have a smoke
detector in the basement.
Resolution:
The agency went to the relative caregivers’ home on 8/1/23. The caregivers
reported their dog was in the basement the day of the Analyst visit for safety reason.
Photos were provided of the basement showing the installed smoke detectors. The
basement area has a free and clear passage to the steps in case of fire. Photos
were attached to the alert.

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that Samaritas Bay agency will be issued a renewal of their regular
license.
